snippet.textDisplay: Time to stand up and be counted, Steven. The next few days will tell us if you have the mettle to be the manager and make big decisions - you're not a player anymore. You need to change the captaincy (rotate to get it right if necessary, including trying out captain/vice-captain rotation to see who wants it). You need to realise that you can't use these same 12-14 players - some past their prime - in games every few days as if we're Liverpool (regardless of how fit  you think they are/your preseason(s) demanded of them). Bleed the youngsters and call back those sent out on loan. You also need to have not just a plan B but C and D. If it comes to doing something radical to break teams down - like giving them the ball and seeing them crack and wait to pounce - then do it. Rangers fans only want success and to win football matches; we don't care how we do it. We don't know the ins and outs of the Morelos situation but if it is a case of him testing your mettle again then the next time it happens he needs to be shown the door. If you can show something from the above in the next few days and weeks then I think Rangers fans will largely back you and support you by believing you could be the Rangers manager needed to stop 10 in a row. If not, then we'll need to find someone who can ... before the split.
snippet.textOriginal: Time to stand up and be counted, Steven. The next few days will tell us if you have the mettle to be the manager and make big decisions - you're not a player anymore. You need to change the captaincy (rotate to get it right if necessary, including trying out captain/vice-captain rotation to see who wants it). You need to realise that you can't use these same 12-14 players - some past their prime - in games every few days as if we're Liverpool (regardless of how fit  you think they are/your preseason(s) demanded of them). Bleed the youngsters and call back those sent out on loan. You also need to have not just a plan B but C and D. If it comes to doing something radical to break teams down - like giving them the ball and seeing them crack and wait to pounce - then do it. Rangers fans only want success and to win football matches; we don't care how we do it. We don't know the ins and outs of the Morelos situation but if it is a case of him testing your mettle again then the next time it happens he needs to be shown the door. If you can show something from the above in the next few days and weeks then I think Rangers fans will largely back you and support you by believing you could be the Rangers manager needed to stop 10 in a row. If not, then we'll need to find someone who can ... before the split.

snippet.textDisplay: The buck does stop with Gerrard but his players offered us absolutely nothing I just hope he doesn’t walk at the end of the season because of this,this realistically was our last chance at silverware this season and as per usual we weren’t up to it it’s hard to work out what has happened to us after the winter break as this is 2 years on the trot this has happened fair enough we’re in the last 16 of the europa and it helps us out financially and is a great achievement but our bread and butter Is the league and stopping Celtic getting further ahead and us as fans will always support the famous through thick and thin but some of these players need a reality check on how this affects us the fans especially after a very lacklustre performance against the worst team in the league like I say I just hope Gerrard doesn’t walk at the end of the season thinking he’s done all he can here.....rant over !! 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁳󠁣󠁴󠁿🔴⚪️🔵🇬🇧

snippet.textDisplay: I think there's a balance that needs to be weighed when conveying a sense of what's possible with the reality of the circumstances. I still believe in Stevie G, and I'm backing him 100%.

snippet.textDisplay: Literally only here would you hear ‘sack the manager’ when you are in 2nd place, 25 points clear of 3rd and in the last 16 of Europa league.  It’s mental.  We HAVE improved but so to have Celtic, that’s the issue!  I bet we finish this season with more points than Celtic it won the league with last season.  I love Gerrard and I especially love his honesty in interviews, good and bad!  I seriously hope he is not made to feel unwelcome by us!

We need somebody to take the game by the scruff of the neck and we dont have anybody capable of that.
Winning in europe is fantastic but that aint gonna cut no mustard if 10 in a row happens.
Those who didnt perform need to take a long hard look at themselves, there are 50 thousand every other week at Ibrox and they demand better if your not up for a fight get yersel to f***.

snippet.textDisplay:
I remember watching Stevie review his playing career in interviews with Rio and later JT.
What struck me was that he was clearly more haunted by the lows than delighted by the highs.
He probably is more obsessed with winning than anyone else I can recall and that is probably part of the reason for his greatness.
He is obviously gutted and considering his future. As much as he may be disappointed in his players, he may also be doubting himself in terms of game preparation, motivation and tactics. Tonight, he is in good company.
Jurgen Klopp seems at a loss to explain his side's inept showing today or their indifferent form since the break.
Brendan Rodgers, meanwhile, is wondering how his Leicester side lost last night to the bottom team in the league. LCFC have 1 win in 7 and are goalless in the last 3.
There are some parallels.
All 3 clubs have failed to recapture the outstanding form they had in the run up to the New Year and all have been affected by the loss of key players.
LFC are desperately missing Hendo and Lovren had a mare replacing Gomez.
LCFC are without Vardy and Ndidi just came back from injury.
Today the Gers played with a third-choice striker and started Hagi on the bench.
I described the team that won in Braga as eleven warriors and still stand by that. The manager probably asked them to leave everything they had on the pitch and they did just that. They are not machines. Stevie can only walk away from them if he can put his hand on his heart and swear he never had a stinker as a player.
I took my first Middle East posting in Bahrain when I was 28. The first six months were a nightmare. The training I was promised did not materialize and I was given 6 projects to manage on my first day. I was chucked in the deep end and nearly drowned. Later, my boss challenged me to resign, but a voice inside my head said "no effing chance of me leaving, until I am a recognized star here." I stayed and only left with my head held high when I was the top performer there.
Finally, Stevie may pause to reflect on the many fans doing dead-end jobs to feed their families. They would love to quit and walk away, but can't.
In the immortal words of General Grant at the Battle of Shiloh after a disastrous first day, "We'll lick 'em tomorrow."
And as Michael Collins once said to De Valera, I say to Stevie; "you were always my chief."
(Sorry for this being so long-winded. )
snippet.textOriginal:
I remember watching Stevie review his playing career in interviews with Rio and later JT. 
What struck me was that he was clearly more haunted by the lows than delighted by the highs. 
He probably is more obsessed with winning than anyone else I can recall and that is probably part of the reason for his greatness.
He is obviously gutted and considering his future. As much as he may be disappointed in his players, he may also be doubting himself in terms of game preparation, motivation and tactics.  Tonight, he is in good company.
Jurgen Klopp seems at a loss to explain his side's inept showing today or their indifferent form since the break.
Brendan Rodgers, meanwhile, is wondering how his Leicester side lost last night to the bottom team in the league. LCFC have 1 win in 7 and are goalless in the last 3. 
There are some parallels. 
All 3 clubs have failed to recapture the outstanding form they had in the run up to the New Year and all have been affected by the loss of key players. 
LFC are desperately missing Hendo and Lovren had a mare replacing Gomez. 
LCFC are without Vardy and Ndidi just came back from injury. 
Today the Gers played with a third-choice striker and started Hagi on the bench. 
I described the team that won in Braga as eleven warriors and still stand by that. The manager probably asked them to leave everything they had on the pitch and they did just that. They are not machines. Stevie can only walk away from them if he can put his hand on his heart and swear he never had a stinker as a player.
I took my first Middle East posting in Bahrain when I was 28. The first six months were a nightmare. The training I was promised did not materialize and I was given 6 projects to manage on my first day. I was chucked in the deep end and nearly drowned. Later, my boss challenged me to resign, but  a voice inside my head said "no effing chance of me leaving, until I am a recognized star here."  I stayed and only left with my head held high when I was the top performer there.
Finally, Stevie may pause to reflect on the many fans doing dead-end jobs to feed their families. They would love to quit and walk away, but can't.
In the immortal words of General Grant at the Battle of Shiloh after a disastrous first day, "We'll lick 'em tomorrow."
And as Michael Collins once said to De Valera, I say to Stevie; "you were always my chief."
(Sorry for this being so long-winded. )

snippet.textDisplay: The players where bad no doubt about it but the decisions made tactically by Gerrard where baffling ojo and Defoe should never of came on Defoe struggled against hearts last time and ojo is a passenger
snippet.textOriginal: The players where bad no doubt about it but the decisions made tactically by Gerrard where baffling ojo and Defoe should never of came on Defoe struggled against hearts last time and ojo is a passenger

snippet.textDisplay:
My honest assessment: Hearts were right up for it - first to
every ball, hunting in packs, gave us no time on the ball, and
pressed high up the pitch. We tried to play football through and around
them, instead of playing the ball over the top and in behind. That's the
only way to beat a high press. The referee was shocking for both
teams. The Hearts player should have gotten a red card, but just before
that they should have had a penalty. Edmundson had two headers on goal,
and should have scored one at least. We looked like a team with
a European hangover, and they looked like they could run all
day. Well done Hearts. The irony is they can't lift their game against
other teams and will likely get relegated.
snippet.textOriginal:

day. Well done Hearts. The irony is they can't lift their game against 
other teams and will likely get relegated.

snippet.textDisplay: Its total meltdown of Rangers and Stevie is right to walk away from this disaster.
snippet.textOriginal: Its total meltdown of Rangers and Stevie is right to walk away from this disaster.

snippet.textDisplay:
I believe Gerrard should be tougher with the players and ask more from them. Who doesn't perform well should be out without question!
When a team loses, let's be honest, the 1st to be blamed is the coach. He didn't succeed in motivating them to win.
I like Gerrard though.
